newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Plains cattle bid $67.00, passed - feedlots.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Plains cattle bid $67.00, passed - feedlots.

text.p: U.S. Plains feedlot cattle early Tuesday were again bid at $67.00 per cwt, but passed by owners asking $69.00 to $70.00, feedlot sources said.
Sales were not expected to occur until Wednesday as packers reportedly had sufficient live inventories until then following last week's trade, they said.
The bulk of last week's sales were at $67.00, although a few head were reported late at $68.00.
"It's going to be another day or two before something happens, and then it will either be $68.00 or $69.00," a Panhandle-area feedlot manager said.
Fed cattle prices were expected to be underpinned by outlooks for continued strong beef prices and light supplies of market-ready cattle on this week's showlists, they said.
Beef on Monday was quoted up $0.83 to $1.33 per cwt, with 115 fabricated loads reported sold, USDA said.
Heavier-weight choice beef was quoted up $1.06 at $102.84, up $3.59 since prices turned higher last Thursday, USDA statistics showed.
Strength in the beef was tied to revived demand as retailers book orders for beef promotions aimed near the end of the month, market sources said.
